ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class taught us how to try to grasp the complexities of narrative questions in the climate crisis. I also had the opportunity to synthesize that with creative practice
A really great environmental humanities class that I am glad I had the opportunity to take!
Reading, writing, and discussing the role of the humanities in addressing climate change

I learned about some of the more complicated social, political, and cultural facets of the climate crisis. I also learned how to more effectively read and digest literature and write effective reading responses. Furthermore, I got to further hone my creative writing and short story skills.
We explored so many different aspects of environmental criticism and narrative climate change through literature, art, and current affairs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course does a great job of covering a large amount of very interesting pieces of literature ranging from novels all the way to court documents. Another strength of this course is that it was highly influenced by the class and like a proper seminar our discussions were largely student led and were highly engaging. The only weakness of this course was simply the large amount of reading that was required.

I had a wonderful time in this course. I think the readings were deeply thought-provoking and I enjoyed writing essays and reflections on the readings. I think the long class period could have benefitted from a bit more structured discussion, but found the presentations and discussion highly fascinating.

I loved all of the different mediums we were diving into, and how our conversations were super expansive, which I could think discussions about the climate crisis ought to be. I really enjoyed Dr. Brass' powerpoints that helped us situate arguments and analyses we were learning to one another. Dr. Brass had great energy and enthusiasm throughout the semester. There could be a bit more organization and stricter deadlines. I really liked the student presentations, and I think it could have been interesting to see more of them (i.e. make them mandatory).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, very very interesting and rich course materials

Yes, if you would like to learn about the ins and outs of the climate crisis from the lens of literature and the humanities this is exactly the class for you. The material is very approachable from the perspectives and knowledge of any major.
Yes!! I learned so much and we had great conversations. I feel like it was a great introduction to ecocriticism in a way that was not pretentious or offputting.
